Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that "Nobody on Medicaid" will have their benefits taken away, while the expert's verdict shows that the Republican plan is projected to reduce federal Medicaid spending by $880 billion and reduce enrollment by 14 million.
Understate: The claim understates the impact of the Republican plan on Medicaid by claiming that nobody will have their benefits taken away, despite the projected reductions in federal Medicaid spending and enrollment.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to back up the assertion that nobody on Medicaid will have their benefits taken away, as the expert's verdict provides evidence of the projected reductions in federal Medicaid spending and enrollment.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes the problematic assumption that the Republican plan will not result in any changes to Medicaid until 2020, which is contradicted by the expert's verdict that the changes will almost certainly result in reduced enrollment.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for the projected reductions in federal Medicaid spending and enrollment, such as the lowering of the federal match rate for new applicants and the potential loss of coverage for those who enrolled under Obamacare.
